summary: A letter from defense attorney Bobbi C. Sternheim to Judge J. Nathan regarding the conditions of Ghislaine Maxwell's pretrial detention at the Metropolitan Detention Center. The letter disputes government claims that Maxwell used a cart to barricade a door and argues that fluctuating restrictions on her access to legal materials hinder her trial preparation.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Author of the letter, representing Ghislaine Maxwell and disputing government claims about Maxwell's conduct and detention conditions.

persons.name: J. Nathan
persons.context: Recipient of the letter, presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the case, currently detained at the Metropolitan Detention Center. The letter defends her against government allegations and describes restrictions on her access to legal materials.

connections.description: Sternheim is the defense attorney representing Maxwell, as evidenced by her filing this letter on Maxwell's behalf.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judge over Maxwell's criminal case.

events.title: Defense Letter Filed Regarding Detention Conditions
events.description: Defense attorney Bobbi C. Sternheim files a letter with Judge Nathan disputing government claims about Maxwell's conduct and arguing that restrictions on her access to legal materials in the VTC room hinder trial preparation.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The government accused Ghislaine Maxwell of using a cart to barricade the door to a VTC (Video Teleconference) room, which her defense attorney Bobbi C. Sternheim categorically denies.
Maxwell's access to legal materials for VTC sessions is restricted by fluctuating rules set by rotating MDC guard teams, which her attorney claims impacts her trial preparation.
Maxwell is not allowed to leave the VTC room during sessions to retrieve additional legal documents she may need to consult with her counsel.
